author: @le_parisien
title: Qui est Laurent Vinatier, le chercheur Fran√ßais arr√™t√© par la Russie pour espionnage ?
text:
Qui est Laurent Vinatier, le chercheur fran√ßais arr√™t√© par la Russie pour espionnage ?
Ce Fran√ßais de 47 ans travaille pour le Centre pour le dialogue humanitaire (DH), une ONG suisse. Il devrait √™tre prochainement inculp√© pour non-enregistrement en tant qu‚Äô¬´ agent de l‚Äô√©tranger ¬ª et encourt jusqu‚Äô√† cinq ans de prison en Russie.
Titulaire d‚Äôun doctorat, membre d‚Äôune ONG suisse, auteurs de plusieurs ouvrages‚Ä¶ Alors que le Comit√© d‚Äôenqu√™te russe de Moscou a annonc√© ce jeudi
avoir arr√™t√© un Fran√ßais soup√ßonn√© d‚Äôavoir collect√© des informations sur l‚Äôarm√©e russe, on fait le point sur ce que l‚Äôon sait du profil de ce ressortissant.
L‚Äôhomme en question est Laurent Vinatier, a pr√©cis√© l‚Äôagence √©tatique russe
Tass. Ce Fran√ßais de 47 ans travaille pour le Centre pour le dialogue humanitaire (DH), une ONG suisse, en tant que conseiller pour la Russie et l‚ÄôEurasie. L‚Äôorganisation a confirm√© √† Reuters l‚Äôarrestation de son employ√©. ¬´ Nous nous effor√ßons d‚Äôobtenir plus de d√©tails sur les circonstances (de l‚Äôarrestation) et d‚Äôobtenir la lib√©ration de Laurent ¬ª, a d√©taill√© l‚ÄôONG aupr√®s de nos confr√®res du Figaro.
Une ONG active ¬´ dans la plupart des conflits mondiaux ¬ª
Le Centre pour le dialogue humanitaire intervient depuis 1999 pour ¬´ aider √† pr√©venir, att√©nuer et r√©soudre les conflits arm√©s par le dialogue et la m√©diation ¬ª. L‚ÄôONG est active ¬´ dans la plupart des conflits mondiaux avec des projets de m√©diation dans diverses r√©gions d‚ÄôAfrique, du Moyen-Orient, d‚ÄôEurasie et d‚ÄôAsie ¬ª, peut-on lire sur son site.
Laurent Vinatier ¬´ travaille pour une organisation non gouvernementale suisse qui a √©t√© fond√©e par l‚Äôancien secr√©taire g√©n√©ral des Nations Unies, Kofi Annan, et qui fait de la diplomatie, des travaux de discussions ¬ª, avait pr√©c√©demment indiqu√© Emmanuel Macron,
lors d‚Äôune interview sur TF1 et France 2.
Titulaire d‚Äôun doctorat
Titulaire d‚Äôun doctorat de l‚ÄôInstitut d‚Äô√âtudes politiques de Paris qui porte sur le conflit en Tch√©tch√©nie, Laurent Vinatier est √©galement l‚Äôauteur de plusieurs ouvrages sur la Russie, le Caucase et l‚ÄôAsie centrale. Avant de rejoindre l‚ÄôONG suisse, ce chercheur de profession avait notamment travaill√© avec le Comit√© international de la Croix-Rouge et au ¬´ Small Arms Survey ¬ª, sur des mouvements islamistes en Syrie et au Nord Caucase, relate le site
Eurasiapeace, pour lequel il √©tait intervenu √† l‚Äôoccasion d‚Äôun podcast.
Laurent Vinatier a √©galement enseign√© √† l‚ÄôUniversit√© Bilgi √† Istanbul sur les mobilisations des diasporas, avant de rejoindre le Centre d‚Äô√âtudes russes et eurasiatiques √† l‚ÄôUniversit√© d‚ÄôUppsala pour travailler sur les mouvements d‚Äôopposition en r√©gimes autocratiques.
Des ¬´ protections consulaires ¬ª activ√©es
Laurent Vinatier devrait √™tre prochainement inculp√© pour non-enregistrement en tant qu‚Äô¬´ agent de l‚Äô√©tranger ¬ª et encourt jusqu‚Äô√† cinq ans de prison. La commission d‚Äôenqu√™te de l‚Äô√âtat russe a indiqu√© que le Fran√ßais √©tait soup√ßonn√©, pendant plusieurs ann√©es d‚Äôavoir ¬´ d√©lib√©r√©ment collect√© des informations dans le domaine des activit√©s militaires et militaro-techniques ¬ª de la Russie.
Des centaines de personnes, militants des droits humains, opposants ou journalistes ind√©pendants, ont √©t√© class√©es en Russie ces derni√®res ann√©es ¬´ agents de l‚Äô√©tranger ¬ª, ce qui s‚Äôaccompagne de strictes contraintes administratives et de l‚Äôobligation de s‚Äôafficher comme tels dans toute communication publique.
Une accusation d‚Äôespionnage pour le compte de Paris √† peine voil√©e et aussi t√¥t d√©mentie par Emmanuel Macron, qui l‚Äôassure : ¬´ En aucun cas ce n‚Äô√©tait quelqu‚Äôun qui travaillait et qui travaille pour la France ¬ª. ¬´ Nous sommes tr√®s vigilants. Il recevra toutes les protections consulaires qui convient dans un tel cas ¬ª, a tenu √† rassurer Emmanuel Macron.

author: Angela Hatke
title: Return to Crystal River: Celebrating the Release of 3 Rescued Manatees
text:
Return to Crystal River: Celebrating the Release of 3 Rescued Manatees
Orphaned manatees Calliope, Piccolina & Soleil were rescued in 2021 and lived at the Cincinnati Zoo for about a year for rehabilitation. Since they hit their goal weight of at least 6oo pounds, they were finally ready to be released back into Florida waters this week!
The three orphaned manatees were rescued by the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) from different areas of southwest Florida in the spring and summer of 2021. The girls were quite small when they were rescued. Soleil weighed 53lbs, Calliope 62 lbs and Piccolina (‚Äúlittle one‚Äù in Italian) was the smallest at 44lbs.
All three required bottle feeding and intensive care for several months. When they arrived at the Cincinnati Zoo they each weighed over 350lbs but needed to hit that 600 pound milestone to be considered for release back into the wild.
The Cincinnati Zoo‚Äôs job as a second-stage rehabilitation facility is to provide plenty of food, primarily lettuce, and veterinary care until the manatees are big and strong enough to return to their native Florida waters!
The Cincinnati Zoo is proud to be a part of the
Manatee Rescue & Rehabilitation Partnership (MRP). We are one of only a handful of places outside of Florida where people can see manatees and learn more about what can be done to protect them.
As the Florida manatee population continues to struggle with watercraft injuries, severe weather, red tide, and the UME (unusual mortality event) due to a decline in food availability along the Atlantic coast that started in 2020, many young manatees become orphans and in need of human assistance. That‚Äôs why the MRP was established and remains critical to the survival of this charismatic species.
Currently the Cincinnati Zoo is caring for orphaned manatees Waffles, Nolia and Amethyst.
Photos from Calliope, Piccolina & Soleil‚Äôs release at Crystal River, Florida with keepers Remy & Tara.

title: Ground News - West Africa's early heat wave signals climate change's impact
text:

author: @berniezilio
title: J.K. Rowling celebrates after UK Supreme Court rules trans women are not legally women
text:
‚ÄòProud‚Äô J.K. Rowling celebrates after UK Supreme Court rules trans women are not legally women
J.K. Rowling celebrated after the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom ruled Wednesday that transgender women are not legally women.
‚ÄúIt took three extraordinary, tenacious Scottish women with an army behind them to get this case heard by the Supreme Court and, in winning, they‚Äôve protected the rights of women and girls across the UK,‚Äù the ‚ÄúHarry Potter‚Äù author, 59, wrote via X.
‚Äú@ForWomenScot, I‚Äôm so proud to know you.‚Äù
Rowling added in another post that she ‚Äúdefinitely has‚Äù given money to the For Women Scotland organization, which has been ‚Äúworking to protect and strengthen women and children‚Äôs rights.‚Äù
She also ‚Äútoasted to‚Äù the women of the group and uploaded a photo of two glasses of champagne before announcing, ‚ÄúThink I might be having a cigar later.‚Äù
Rowling later argued, ‚ÄúThe Supreme Court upheld the rights of women and gay people today.‚Äù
However, a trans woman called the ‚Äúextreme‚Äù ruling an ‚Äúinjustice,‚Äù elaborating that the court ‚Äúhad a hearing about what rights, what freedoms, what future trans people have‚Ä¶ without a single trans person being involved, yet multiple with hate groups.‚Äù
Want more celebrity and pop culture news?
Start your day with Page Six Daily.
Thanks for signing up!
She added, ‚ÄúThey decided we don‚Äôt deserve equality.‚Äù
Rowling retorted, ‚ÄúThe court clarified that UK women have sex-based rights. You and your fellow activists‚Äô meltdowns are laying bare what has been obvious to a lot of us for years: when you say ‚Äòequality‚Äô you mean ‚Äòwomen have no right, under any circumstances, to draw boundaries that exclude men.'‚Äù
According to the author, the ‚Äúwinners‚Äù of the ruling include ‚Äúwomen and girls, including trans-identified women (continue to benefit from maternity rights etc), gay people, freedom of speech, freedom of association [and] those at risk of discrimination for a belief in the material reality of sex.‚Äù
The court‚Äôs five judges agreed in the landmark decision that ‚Äúthe terms ‚Äòwoman‚Äô and ‚Äòsex'‚Äù under the UK‚Äôs 2010 Equality Act ‚Äúrefer to a biological woman and biological sex,‚Äù Justice Patrick Hodge said.
The ruling ‚Äúdoes not remove protection from trans people,‚Äù who are ‚Äúprotected from discrimination on the ground of gender reassignment,‚Äù the court confirmed ‚Äî but a transgender person with documentation recognizing them as female should not be considered a woman for equality purposes.
Rowling has a long history of anti-trans views and even once proclaimed that she would ‚Äúhappily‚Äù go to prison for her beliefs.

author: Reuters
title: UK saw second-warmest year on record in 2023, says Met Office By Reuters
text:
¬© Reuters. FILE PHOTO: A man drinks from a bottle at Primrose Hill, in London, Britain, September 3, 2023. REUTERS/Hollie Adams/File Photo LONDON (Reuters) -Britain experienced its second-warmest year on record in 2023, the Met Office national weather service said on Tuesday, pointing to the growing impact of human-induced climate change on the country's average temperatures.
Provisional figures from the Met Office showed last year's mean temperature of 9.97 degrees Celsius fell just below 2022's 10.03 C but was ahead of 2014's 9.88 C. The records date back to 1884.
The UK's 10 warmest years have all occurred in the 21st century and more temperature records are set to be broken in coming years, the weather forecaster said.
Hotter temperatures could heighten the risk of drought and wildfires, intense rainfall and flooding, potentially harming ecosystems, human health and infrastructure like airport runways and railway tracks.
"While our climate will remain variable, with periods of cold and wet weather, what we have observed over recent decades is a number of high temperature records tumbling," Met Office Senior Scientist Mike Kendon said.
That pattern was expected to continue "in the coming years as a result of human-induced climate change."
Climate warming in the UK comes amid global temperature records that were likely broken last year. In October, the EU climate service said 2023 was on track to be the world's hottest year since at least 1940.
Despite agreement reached at the COP28 summit last month in Dubai for the world to transition away from fossil fuels, scientists say it isn't enough to limit global warming below a 1.5 C benchmark target.
A sustained rise beyond that target would trigger catastrophic and irreversible impacts, from melting ice sheets to the collapse of ocean currents, scientists say.
In the UK, heatwaves in June and September, as well as above-average temperatures for eight out of 12 months last year contributed to the record, the Met Office said.
Wales and Northern Ireland had their warmest years on record last year, it added.
UK saw second-warmest year on record in 2023, says Met Office

author: Joseph S. Pete joseph.pete@nwi.com, 219-933-3316
title: Franciscan Health Crown Point hospitalist wins honor
text: A hospitalist at Franciscan Health Crown Point Hospital was honored with a St. Raphael Award. The nursing staff at the hospital selected Dr. Ahmer Festok for the honor to recognize him for his "outstanding dedication, teamwork and respect for the nursing staff at Franciscan Health Crown Point and for his commitment to the mission and values at Franciscan Alliance." The award is named after St. Raphael, the archangel from the Christian, Judaic and Islamic faiths who became the Catholic church's patron saint of travelers, the blind, happy meetings, matchmakers, nurses, physicians and other medical workers. The nurses Tisha Casey, Julie Kruzan and Mindy Palmquist nominated Dr. Festok based on his compassionate care for patients and respect for nurses. The nurses with the Progressive Care Unit noted that he develops relationships with the nurses taking care of the patients at the hospital People are also reading‚Ä¶ Festok is a graduate of the Alabama College of Osteopathic Medicine who did an internal medicine residency at the Northeast Georgia Hospital System. He practices medicine as a hospitalist, meaning that he only works inside a hospital to treat admitted patients. NWI Business Ins and Outs: Mi Tierra closing after 22 years; La Carreta, Flako's Tacos, Wendy's, Bulldog Ale House, WhoaZone, The Love of Arts and Illinois Dermatology Institute opening Opening Closing Coming soon Open Open Open Open Anniversary Leased 219 News Now 6/23/23 NWI Business Ins and Outs: Maple + Bacon, deli and Divalicious Desserts Bakery & Cafe opening

author: Evan Bland World-Herald Staff Writer
title: Youthful wave of Nebraska players relishing bowl opportunity
text:
NEW YORK ‚Äî Vincent Shavers wore a grin and a black practice jersey he‚Äôd been eyeing all season. The Miami kid never would have guessed the next step in his college football career would play out in the snowy Big Apple.
Not that the Nebraska freshman linebacker hasn‚Äôt done plenty already in his Husker debut. He is the only 2024 signee to appear in every regular-season game as a steady contributor on defense while making plays on special teams too.
His role in Saturday‚Äôs Pinstripe Bowl will be more. Through merit. And because multiple other NU linebackers transferred elsewhere. He‚Äôll rotate with seniors John Bullock and Javin Wright against a run-heavy Boston College attack.
‚ÄúI kept working, kept working, staying patient waiting for my time to come,‚Äù Shavers said Thursday after a brisk and sunny practice at Fordham‚Äôs home stadium in the Bronx. ‚ÄúJust kept putting in the work and finally got my Blackshirt. I‚Äôm proud, I‚Äôm happy, I‚Äôm ready to work.‚Äù
People are also reading‚Ä¶ Name of fire victim released, investigation remains ongoing Fremont's Juan Gonzalez commits to University of Oregon What‚Äôs open and closed on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day 2024? Methodist Fremont Health globally recognized for nursing excellence Fremont Police Log Inside Matt Rhule's 'pretty insane gesture' of getting former Huskers to the Pinstripe Bowl Midland University, Fremont Public Schools team up to offer Direct Admissions Program Nebraska football lands Idaho defensive back transfer Andrew Marshall Is John Dutton real? Meet the powerful rancher seemingly inspiring the 'Yellowstone' legend 3 Nebraska starters still with team to miss bowl game with mix of injuries, opt outs Making his mark: Special Olympics athlete, representative visits the White House Amie Just: Missed opportunities sting Nebraska volleyball in painful loss in Final Four Dodge County Real Estate Transfers Nebraska volleyball libero Lexi Rodriguez signs with LOVB's Omaha team Nebraska wins Diamond Head Classic crown behind Brice Williams' MVP performance Saturday is about winning one more game for the seniors, Shavers said. It‚Äôs also about the next wave of Huskers setting a tone inside Yankee Stadium for what‚Äôs to come in 2025. Nebraska‚Äôs depth chart is littered with names of those getting an opportunity amid transfers and opt-outs. Many of those snaps will become harder to earn when a fresh crop of portal additions and high-school signees arrive in January.
Chances abound at defensive line where ‚Äî beyond outgoing seniors Ty Robinson and Nash Hutmacher ‚Äî new contributors must emerge on a more full-time basis next season. Riley Van Poppel is a lead candidate to do so now free from redshirt restrictions. His first trip to New York City has been fun, he said, but now it‚Äôs time to win a game. That‚Äôs the top priority.
‚ÄúGo out there and get a win to not only finish this year right‚Ä¶ but then that leads you into next year,‚Äù the 6-foot-5, 290-pound Van Poppel said. ‚ÄúThat really sets the tone for when we get back in January for winter workouts how those go, spring ball and then next season. This game is going to show a lot about who our team is next year.‚Äù
The extra bowl work ‚Äî something Nebraska hasn‚Äôt had in eight winters ‚Äî means more runway for what‚Äôs coming. Like culture, with coach Matt Rhule emphasizing that trips like this are a chance to act like professionals and leave places better than players found them. Like development, with former quarterback Heinrich Haarberg leaning more into a shift to tight end as one example of bowl-season tinkering.
Like relationships too. Shavers is around snow for just the second time in his life, he said. But this is the first time he‚Äôs spent this much quality time with teammates at any level, touring the 9/11 memorial and snowball fight in Central Park included. It‚Äôs leaving him thankful and motivated.
‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs happy,‚Äù Shavers said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a brotherhood. We family. I‚Äôm happy for them. It‚Äôs all for the seniors.‚Äù
Shavers, perhaps not jokingly, said he‚Äôs embracing a bigger role Saturday even if it means playing long snapper or safety or something else. A glance at the defensive depth chart suggests he won‚Äôt be alone with the likes of underclassmen like linemen Keona Davis and Van Poppel, linebacker Dylan Rogers, rover Rahmir Stewart, safety Caleb Benning and others to potentially see their first extended looks.
Shavers is the latest success story from Nebraska‚Äôs Miami freshmen after Jacory Barney, who broke out quickly as the team‚Äôs leading pass-catcher. Linebacker Willis McGahee IV is also seeing a role increase while defensive backs Amare Sanders and Larry Tarver continue to impress behind the scenes.
New receivers coach Daikiel Shorts called the value of bowl practices ‚Äúphenomenal.‚Äù They‚Äôve helped him integrate quicker into the program in the few weeks since he left Kentucky. They‚Äôve provided more practice repetitions to rising playmakers like Jaylen Lloyd and Carter Nelson.
One game left to show the gains. Then take that momentum in a carry-on back to Nebraska and into an offseason blessedly shorter than the Huskers are used to navigating.
‚ÄúAll the younger guys, we know what to do,‚Äù Shavers said. ‚ÄúWe know the standard. Let‚Äôs get it done. We don‚Äôt got time to be playing no more. It‚Äôs going to be our show.‚Äù

author: PA News Agency
title: Yellow weather warning in place for rain and snow | Glasgow Times
text:
A yellow weather warning for rain and snow has been issued for much of Scotland on Saturday.
The warning is in place from 8am until 3pm on Saturday and up to 25mm of rain is expected in lower levels of Scotland, according to the Met Office.
A period of sleet and snow, turning to rain on Saturday, may lead to some flooding and travel disruption.
Bus and train services may be affected, with journey times taking longer, with some spray and flooding on roads.
Yellow weather warnings are in place for rain and snow in Scotland on Saturday, December 30 (PA Graphics) Some interruption to power services is also likely.
This week, Storm Gerrit caused travel disruption across the UK.
Hundreds of homes in Scotland remain without power as the post-storm clean-up begins, but electricity bosses are ‚Äúvery confident‚Äù that the remaining properties will be reconnected on Friday.
Travellers faced disruption across the rail network with operators urging passengers to check their journeys before setting off.
The last few days of 2023 are forecast to be unsettled, with strong winds, rain and even snow featuring in parts of the UK.
Find out more in our latest press release üëá
‚Äî Met Office (@metoffice) December 29, 2023
Andy Page, Met Office chief forecaster, said: ‚ÄúParts of the higher ground of Scotland may see temporary snow accumulations of 5-10cm (1-2in), while up to 25mm (just under 1in) of rain is expected in Wales, Northern Ireland and lower levels in Scotland.
‚ÄúAcross Wales and southern England, wind gusts of 45-50mph are likely to be quite widespread, while gusts of 65-75mph are possible in the most exposed coastal areas.‚Äù
